title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: In this fashion it came about that we found ourselves once more in Scotland. We landed at Dumbarton, from whilk place we went on with lord Fleming and the Frenchman to Niddrie, where I had my first view of the Secretar, who had come out from Embro to confer with the Ambassador. But, alack ! what a change was there in him.

title: Witch stories,
author: Linton, E. Lynn
snippet: All this did Jonet Forsyth of Birsay, to the terror of her neighbours and the ultimate ruin of herself, both in soul and body. Then came Catherine Oswald,* spouse to Kobert Aitcheson, in Niddrie, who was brought to trial for being " habite and repute " a witch defamed by Elizabeth Toppock herself a witch and, as is so often the case, a dear friend of Katie's. Elizabeth need not have been so eager to get rid of her dear friend and gossip, for she was burnt afterwards for the same crimes as those for which poor Catherine suffered the halter and the stake.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: For many years almost all my Saturdays, Sun days, and holidays, were passed at Niddrie. I sighed over every holiday as lost, that was not.

title: The charm of Edinburgh :
author: Hyatt, Alfred Henry.
snippet: It was not till after she became a woman that she taught herself to read and write ; and then she read incessantly. She must have been about sixty before I ever saw her, which was chiefly, and often, at Niddrie. Her dress was always the same, a man's hat when out of doors, and generally when within them, a cloth covering exactly like a man's great-coat, buttoned closely from the chin to the ground, worsted stockings, strong shoes with large brass clasps.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: After a long and unbroken course of domestic security and pleasure, death began, about 1815, to extinguish, and circumstances to scatter, the gay and amiable family of which I was virtually a member ; and I have since seldom revisited the generally silent walls. But the days of Niddrie are among the last I can forget.
